Substeps.Procedure: User Pam executed payload rcs.3aka3.doc
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process spawning from explorer.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed explorer.exe executing rcs.3aka3.doc.
A General alert detection (low severity) was generated for rcs.3aka3.doc that was identified as "patpoopy" backdoor during execution.

Substeps.Procedure: Used unicode right-to-left override (RTLO) character to obfuscate file name rcs.3aka3.doc (originally cod.3aka.scr)
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence of the right-to-left override character (U+202E) in the rcs.3aka.doc process OR the original filename (cod.3aka.scr)

Detections.Detection_Note: A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Masquerading was generated due to Right-to-Left -Override (RLO) technique being observed on rcs.3aka3.doc

Substeps.Procedure: Established C2 channel (192.168.0.5) via rcs.3aka3.doc payload over TCP port 1234

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the rcs.3aka3.doc process connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP port 1234.
An MSSP detection for "Uncommonly Used Port" was generated due to rcs.3aka3.doc connecting to 192.168.0.5 on port 1234.

Substeps.Procedure: Used RC4 stream cipher to encrypt C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is encrypted

Detections.Detection_Note: Minimum detection criteria was not met for this procedure.

Substeps.Procedure: Spawned interactive cmd.exe
Substeps.Criteria: cmd.exe spawning from the rcs.3aka3.doc process

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed cmd.exe spawning from rcs.3aka3.doc. This event was correlated to a Technique detection for masquerading.

Substeps.Procedure: Spawned interactive powershell.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed cmd.exe spawning powershell.exe.

Substeps.Procedure: Searched filesystem for document and media files using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-ChildItem.
An MSSP detection for Discovery occurred containing evidence that "PowerShell ran commands to query files with multiple extensions and compress the found files into a zip file."

Substeps.Procedure: Scripted search of filesystem for document and media files using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-ChildItem.
An MSSP detection for Collection occurred containing evidence that "PowerShell ran commands to query files with multiple extensions and compressed the found files into a zip file."

Substeps.Procedure: Recursively collected files found in C:\Users\Pam\ using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Minimum detection criteria was not met for this procedure.

Substeps.Procedure: Compressed and stored files into ZIP (Draft.zip) using PowerShell

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe compressing via Compress-Archive.
An MSSP detection for Discovery occurred containing evidence that PowerShell ran commands to query files with certain extensions and compress the found files into a zip file.

Substeps.Procedure: Staged files for exfiltration into ZIP (Draft.zip) using PowerShell

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the creation of Draft.Zip.
An MSSP detection for Discovery occurred containing evidence that PowerShell ran commands to query files with certain extensions and compress the found files into a zip file.

Substeps.Procedure: Read and downloaded ZIP (Draft.zip) over C2 channel (192.168.0.5 over TCP port 1234)
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process reading the file draft.zip while connected to the C2 channel

Technique.Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

Detections.Detection_Note: Minimum detection criteria was not met for this procedure.

Substeps.Procedure: Dropped stage 2 payload (monkey.png) to disk
Substeps.Criteria: The rcs.3aka3.doc process creating the file monkey.png

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection for Defense Evasion occurred containing evidence of monkey.png being uploaded to Nashua.

Substeps.Procedure: Embedded PowerShell payload in monkey.png using steganography
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that a PowerShell payload was within monkey.png

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PowerShell extracting, allocating memory, and executing the code embedded within monkey.png.

A General alert detection (medium severity) for suspicious PowerShell commandline was generated for PowerShell extracting and executing the code embedded within monkey.png. This detection was correlated to a parent General detection of rcs.3aka3.doc being identified as 'patpoopy' backdoor.
An MSSP detection for Defense Evasion occurred containing evidence of the PowerShell script contained within monkey.png.

Substeps.Procedure: Modified the Registry to enable COM hijacking of sdclt.exe using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: Addition of the DelegateExecute subkey in HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the addition of the DelegateExecute Registry Value.
A General alert detection (medium severity) was generated due to a change in Registry value of command key.
An MSSP detection for Defense Evasion was generated due to a Registry key being enabled to permit Component Object Model Hijacking.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed elevated PowerShell payload
Substeps.Criteria: High integrity powershell.exe spawning from control.exe (spawned from sdclt.exe)

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed control.exe creating a high integrity powershell.exe.
A Technique alert detection for UAC bypass (medium severity) was generated. The detection included  sdclt.exe executing with elevated permissions.

Substeps.Procedure: Established C2 channel (192.168.0.5) via PowerShell payload over TCP port 443

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe connecting to 192.168.0.5 on TCP port 443.
An MSSP detection for Defense Evasion was generated containing evidence monkey.png performed C&C over port 443 to IP address 192.168.0.5.

Substeps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to transport C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is HTTPS

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection for Command and Control was generated containing evidence Meterpreter communications were being sent using HTTPS, due to the presence of the WINHTTP_FLAG_SECURE within the embedded shell code.

Substeps.Procedure: Used HTTPS to encrypt C2 (192.168.0.5) traffic
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that the network data sent over the C2 channel is encrypted

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection for Command and Control was generated containing evidence Meterpreter communications are being sent using HTTPS, due to the presence of the WINHTTP_FLAG_SECURE within the embedded shell code.

Substeps.Procedure: Modified the Registry to remove artifacts of COM hijacking

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PowerShell command to remove DelegateExecute Registry Value. This event was correlated to a previous detection for PowerShell.
An MSSP detection for Defense Evasion was generated containing evidence of the deletion of registry key.

Substeps.Procedure: Dropped additional tools (SysinternalsSuite.zip) to disk over C2 channel (192.168.0.5)

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the file write of the ZIP by PowerShell.

Substeps.Procedure: Spawned interactive powershell.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed a new powershell.exe spawning from powershell.exe.

Substeps.Procedure: Decompressed ZIP (SysinternalsSuite.zip) file using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PowerShell decompressing the ZIP via Expand-Archive.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated current running processes using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-Process.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence that multiple local and domain reconnaissance operations were executed. Get-Process was specifically identified in the report.

Substeps.Procedure: Deleted rcs.3aka3.doc on disk using SDelete

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed sdelete.exe running with command-line arguments to delete the file and the subsequent file rename and delete events.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence of sdelete64.exe deleting rcs.3aka3.doc.

Substeps.Procedure: Deleted Draft.zip on disk using SDelete

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed sdelete.exe running with command-line arguments to delete the file and the subsequent file rename and delete events.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence of sdelete64.exe deleting Draft.zip.

Substeps.Procedure: Deleted SysinternalsSuite.zip on disk using SDelete

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed sdelete.exe running with command-line arguments to delete the file and the subsequent file rename and delete events.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence of sdelete64.exe deleting SysinternalsSuite.zip.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated user's temporary directory path using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $env:TEMP. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated the current username using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $env:USERNAME. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated the computer hostname using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $env:COMPUTERNAME. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated the current domain name using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $env:USERDOMAIN. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated the current process ID using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: $PID. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated the OS version using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: Gwmi Win32_OperatingSystem. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated anti-virus software using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: Get-WmiObject ... -Class AntiVirusProduct. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated firewall software using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: Get-WmiObject ... -Class FireWallProduct. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated user's domain group membership via the NetUserGetGroups API

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing: Invoke-NetUserGetGroups. Script preview was truncated so an alternate view is shown.
An MSSP detection for "Yttrium High Active Alert related to Discovery on a machine in your environment" occurred containing evidence of PowerShell command Invoke-NetUserGetGroups.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed API call by reflectively loading Netapi32.dll
Substeps.Criteria: The NetUserGetGroups API function loaded into powershell.exe from Netapi32.dll

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed Netapi32.dll loaded into powershell.exe.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated user's local group membership via the NetUserGetLocalGroups API

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing the NetUserGetLocalGroups API.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence of PowerShell executing Invoke-NetUserGetLocalGroups.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed API call by reflectively loading Netapi32.dll
Substeps.Criteria: The NetUserGetLocalGroups API function loaded into powershelle.exe from Netapi32.dll

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the NetUserGetLocalGroups API function loaded into PowerShell from Netapi32.dll.

Substeps.Procedure: Created a new service (javamtsup) that executes a service binary (javamtsup.exe) at system startup

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed a registry event for the creation of javamtsup service.

A Technique alert detection for "Suspicious Service registration" (medium severity) was generated due to the creation of javamtsup service. This detection was correlated to a parent General detection that rcs.3aka3.doc was identified as a backdoor.

Substeps.Procedure: Created a LNK file (hostui.lnk) in the Startup folder that executes on login
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating the file hostui.lnk in the Startup folder

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

Detections.Detection_Note: A General alert detection (low severity) was generated for "a link file (LNK) with unusual characteristics was opened." This detection was correlated to a parent General detection that rcs.3aka3.doc was identified as a patpoopy.backdoor.

A Technique alert detection (medium severity) for Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder was generated due to the file write of hostui.lnk in the Startup folder. This detection was correlated to a parent General detection of rcs.3aka3.doc being identified as 'patpoopy' backdoor.
An MSSP detection for Persistence was generated due to hostui.lnk being placed inside the Startup folder.

Substeps.Procedure: Read the Chrome SQL database file to extract encrypted credentials

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection for Credential Access was generated containing evidence the Chrome database was read from the machine using accesschk.exe.

Substeps.Procedure: Executed the CryptUnprotectedData API call to decrypt Chrome passwords

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers

Detections.Detection_Note: An MSSP detection for Credential Access was generated containing evidence the CryptUnprotectData API was invoked in order to perform decryption on password data.

Substeps.Procedure: Masqueraded a Chrome password dump tool as accesscheck.exe, a legitimate Sysinternals tool
Substeps.Criteria: Evidence that accesschk.exe is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed hash of accesschk.exe, which can be used to verify it is not the legitimate Sysinternals tool.
A General alert detection was generated for accesschk.exe being detected as "Hacktool:Win32/ChromePassRecovery.A."

Substeps.Procedure: Exported a local certificate to a PFX file using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe creating a certificate file exported from the system

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed file create event for a $RandomFileName.pfx file by powershell.exe.
An MSSP detection for Credential Access was generated containing evidence the private key was exported using PowerShell to the user download folder.

Substeps.Procedure: Dumped password hashes from the Windows Registry by injecting a malicious DLL into Lsass.exe
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe injecting into lsass.exe OR lsass.exe reading Registry keys under HKLM:\SAM\SAM\Domains\Account\Users\

Subtechnique.Subtechnique_Name: OS Credential Dumping: Security Account Manager

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry shows powershell.exe using CreateRemoteThread API call to inject into lsass.exe.
A General alert detection (medium severity) for "suspicious process injection was observed" was generated due to powershell.exe injecting into lsass.exe.

Substeps.Procedure: Captured and saved screenshots using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing the CopyFromScreen function from System.Drawing.dll

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing CopyFromScreen from System.Drawing.dll.
An MSSP detection for Collection was generated containing evidence that a malicious PowerShell script was executed capturing current screen state.

Substeps.Procedure: Captured clipboard contents using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Get-Clipboard.
An MSSP detection for Collection was generated containing evidence that a malicious PowerShell script was executed capturing clipboard information.

Substeps.Procedure: Captured user keystrokes using the GetAsyncKeyState API

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed API calls for GetAsyncKeyState. Though no image was captured, MITRE confirmed that the vendor has the capability to show available telemetry in a separate view.
A Technique alert detection for Input Capture (high severity) was generated due to powershell.exe using APIs that are commonly abused by malicious applications to log keystrokes.

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe executing Compress-7Zip with arguments for encryption.

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PoweShell creating OfficeSupplies.7z on a remote adversary WebDav network share (192.168.0.4).

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated remote systems using LDAP queries

An MSSP detection occurred containing evidence of LDAP queries from Nashua to NewYork (Domain Controller - 10.0.0.4).

Substeps.Procedure: Checked that the BIOS version and serial number are not associated with VirtualBox or VMware using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_BIOS

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_BIOS.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran command to check BIOS version and serial numbers gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'SELECT * FROM Win32_BIOS'.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated computer manufacturer, model, and version information using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject gwmi queries for Win32_BIOS and Win32_ComputerSystem

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi queries for Win32_BIOS and Win32_ComputerSystem.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to check BIOS version and obtain system information.

Substeps.Procedure: Enumerated devices/adapters to check for presence of VirtualBox driver(s) using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_PnPEntity

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_PnPEntity.

An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated  containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to pull properties of Plug and Play devices: gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'SELECT * FROM Win32_PnPEntity'.

Substeps.Procedure: Checked that the username is not related to admin or a generic value (ex: user) using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_ComputerSystem

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_ComputerSystem.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to obtain system information: gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'Select * from Win32_ComputerSystem'.

Substeps.Procedure: Checked that the computer is joined to a domain using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_ComputerSystem

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed powershell.exe gwmi query for Win32_ComputerSystem.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell runs command to obtain system information: gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'Select * from Win32_ComputerSystem'.

Substeps.Procedure: Checked that processes such as procexp.exe, taskmgr.exe, or wireshark.exe are not running using PowerShell
Substeps.Criteria: powershell.exe executing a Get-WmiObject query for Win32_Process

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the PowerShell gwmi query for Win32_Process.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to get process information on the machine: gwmi -namespace root\cimv2 -query 'SELECT * FROM Win32_Process'.

Substeps.Procedure: Checked that the payload is not inside a folder path that contains "sample" or is the length of a hash value using PowerShell

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed PowerShell executing Get-Item for the current path.
An MSSP detection for Discovery was generated containing evidence PowerShell ran commands to enumerate files and directories: (Get-Item -Path '.\' -Verbose).FullName.

Substeps.Procedure: Decoded an embedded DLL payload to disk using certutil.exe

Detections.Detection_Note: Telemetry showed the certutil.exe process and corresponding file write of the kxwn.lock payload.

Substeps.Procedure: Established Registry Run key persistence using PowerShell
